description.narrative: Municipalities, private operators, NGOs and community-based management structures have improved capacity to equitably provide WASH services at the community level, in schools and in health facilities, including in humanitarian situations.

sector.narrative: Water supply - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres)
Water supply - rural communities service delivery

Niger Programme Strategy Note Theory of Change (WASH)
Niger Country Programme Document 2014-2018 Results Matrix
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Municipalities, private operators, NGOs and community-based management structures have improved capacity to equitably provide WASH services at the community level, in schools and in health facilities, including in humanitarian situations.

description.narrative: During 2019, 23,548 additional people gained access to safe drinking water through climate resilient water supply infrastructure thanks to UNICEF direct support. UNICEF supported the conduction of feasibility studies for the construction of 32 new multi-villages piped systems and supported 36 schools and 18 health care facilities to gain access to WASH facilities. The mobilization of a private firm by UNICEF for addition technical support to the government and humanitarian actors and the real-time monitoring of the functionality of water points helped to improve the quality and sustainability of the WASH infrastructure and service | Status:On-track | As-of Date:21/01/2020

title.narrative: Minimum rate of change in the receipts paid by the delegatee in each target commune
Number of municipalities with a public-private partnership that contributes to improving the access rate (to drinking water)
Number of schools with Menstrual Hygiene Management implemented in schools programmes as a result of UNICEF direct support and/or leveraged through national programmes.
Number of municipalities with a functional SMEA (Municipal Water and Sanitation Service)
Number of people accessing a sustainable drinking water service in the reporting year only
Number of schools accessing basic WASH services during the reporting year with direct support from UNICEF
Number of Communities implementing water safety plans
Number of additional people living in the newly certified Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities as a result of UNICEF CATS programming during the year of reporting
Proportion of federations of water public service user associations operating in the target communes
Number of health centers with WASH facilities during the reporting year with direct support from UNICEF
Number of schools supported by UNICEF during the year of reporting with separate sanitation facilities for boys and girls
Number of communities certified free of open defecation in the reporting year only as a result of UNICEF direct support
